entry.title: Coastal Flood Statement issued April 7 at 3:12AM ChST until April 10 at 4:00PM ChST by NWS Tiyan GU
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Isolated minor coastal flooding.
* WHERE...Majuro and nearby atolls.
* WHEN...Through Wednesday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Some water on low lying roads and property.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Increasing surf combined with King Tides will lead to seas increasing to near 7 feet Mean Low Level Water heights. Typically, anything above 6 feet results in minor coastal inundation with water perhaps approaching some roadways, possibly spilling slightly over them as well.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Majuro

cap:parameter.value: COASTAL FLOOD STATEMENT REMAINS IN EFFECT THROUGH WEDNESDAY AFTERNOON

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued April 6 at 11:10AM MDT by NWS Grand Junction CO
entry.summary:
The Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment has issued the following...
WHAT...Air Quality Health Advisory for Blowing Dust.
WHERE...Cheyenne, Fremont, Kiowa, Pueblo, Rio Grande, Alamosa, Baca, Costilla, Conejos, Saguache, Bent, Prowers, Huerfano, Custer, Las Animas, Lincoln, Otero and Archuleta Counties. Locations include, but are not limited to Cheyenne Wells, Canon City, Eads, Pueblo, Del Norte, South Fork, Alamosa, Springfield, San Luis, Conejos, Saguache, Las Animas, Lamar, Walsenburg, Westcliffe, Kim, Trinidad, Limon, La Junta and Pagosa Springs.
WHEN...1100 AM Saturday April 06 to 900 PM Saturday April 06
IMPACTS...Strong and gusty winds will produce areas of blowing dust on Saturday. The threat for blowing dust will gradually diminish by Saturday evening.
HEALTH INFORMATION...Public Health Recommendations: Increasing likelihood of respiratory symptoms in sensitive individuals, aggravation of heart or lung disease and premature mortality in people with cardiopulmonary disease and older adults. People with heart or lung disease, older adults, and children should reduce prolonged or heavy exertion.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Archuleta, CO

cap:parameter.value: AIR QUALITY HEALTH ADVISORY FOR BLOWING DUST FROM 1100 AM SATURDAY UNTIL 900 PM SATURDAY

entry.title: Wind Advisory issued April 6 at 12:06PM CDT until April 6 at 7:00PM CDT by NWS Grand Forks ND
entry.summary:
* WHAT...For the Blowing Dust Advisory, visibility between one quarter mile and one mile in blowing dust. For the Wind Advisory, southeast winds 25 to 35 mph with gusts up to 50 mph.
* WHERE...In Minnesota, Wilkin County. In North Dakota, Cass and Richland Counties.
* WHEN...Until 7 PM CDT this evening.
* IMPACTS...Hazardous driving conditions due to sudden reductions in visibility. Gusty winds could blow around unsecured objects.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Gusty winds combined with very dry air will allow for critical fire weather conditions to develop in the southern Red River Valley. Red Flag Warnings are in effect in areas that these conditions are expected to develop.

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued April 6 at 12:46PM EDT until April 7 at 2:00AM EDT by NWS Caribou ME
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Minor flooding caused by the upstream Vanceboro dam release is expected.
* WHERE...A portion of DownEast Maine, including the following county, Washington.
* WHEN...Until 200 AM EDT Sunday.
* IMPACTS...Minor flooding is occurring of low lying properties on Salmon Brook Road in Vanceboro. Possible minor flooding at camps along the St. Croix River on Loon Bay Road in Lambert Lake Township and Dyer Township. Additional minor flooding in rural areas of Eastern Washington County above the Grand Falls Flowage is expected.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1244 PM EDT, an upstream floodgate release at Vanceboro is expected to continue to cause minor flooding in the advisory area. - As of 12:30PM the flow being released from the Vanceboro Dam is 5943 cfs. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Vanceboro, Dyer Township, Fowler Township, Dyer and Lambert Lake. - For flood safety visit www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Washington, ME

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD ADVISORY FOR A DAM FLOODGATE RELEASE NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL 2 AM EDT SUNDAY

entry.title: Flood Warning issued April 6 at 12:43PM EDT until April 6 at 10:00PM EDT by NWS Charleston WV
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues.
* WHERE...A portion of northern West Virginia, including the following county, Wood.
* WHEN...Until 1000 PM EDT Saturday.
* IMPACTS...Flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations is occurring.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1240 PM EDT, gauge reports indicate flooding of the Little Tygart Creek due to backwater from the Ohio River. Water levels are falling, and are expected to continue to fall. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Mineralwells. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Wood, WV

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued April 6 at 10:35AM MDT until April 7 at 10:00AM MDT by NWS Billings MT
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Snow expected. Total snow accumulations between 2 and 6 inches. Winds gusting as high as 40 mph producing areas of blowing snow.
* WHERE...Judith Gap.
* WHEN...Until 10 AM MDT Sunday.
* IMPACTS...Roads, and especially bridges and overpasses, will likely become slick and hazardous at times. Travel could be very difficult. Blowing snow could significantly reduce visibility.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The heaviest snow will be in the foothills of area mountains, with less snow along the US-191 corridor.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Judith Gap

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued April 6 at 10:35AM MDT until April 7 at 6:00PM MDT by NWS Billings MT
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Wet snow expected. Total snow accumulations of up to 4 inches greatest in the highest hills. Winds gusting as high as 30 mph producing areas of blowing snow.
* WHERE...Southwestern Yellowstone.
* WHEN...Until 6 PM MDT Sunday.
* IMPACTS...Lower elevations, including most populated locations, will see light snow accumulations and minimal travel difficulties. The impactful snow accumulations will be confined to the higher hilltops.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Southwestern Yellowstone

cap:parameter.value: WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 6 PM MDT SUNDAY

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued April 6 at 10:35AM MDT until April 7 at 6:00PM MDT by NWS Billings MT
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Wet snow expected. Total snow accumulations of up to 10 inches in the highest hills. Winds gusting as high as 40 mph producing areas of blowing snow.
* WHERE...Musselshell, Northeastern Yellowstone, Northern Big Horn, and Treasure.
* WHEN...Until 6 PM MDT Sunday.
* IMPACTS...Lower elevations, including most populated locations, will see light snow accumulations and minimal travel difficulties. The impactful snow accumulations will be confined to the higher hilltops, where 5 to 10 inches of heavy wet snow is expected, and locally heavier accumulations are possible. This includes the Hysham Hills and the Bull Mountains.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The heavy wet snow and poor visibility will make rural travel difficult. The combination of gusty winds and wet snow may bring down tree limbs and power lines, resulting in power outages.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Musselshell; Treasure; Northern Big Horn; Northeastern Yellowstone

cap:parameter.value: WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL 6 PM MDT SUNDAY

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued April 6 at 10:35AM MDT until April 8 at 12:00PM MDT by NWS Billings MT
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Wet snow expected. Total snow accumulations up to 18 inches in the highest hilltops and foothills locations. Winds gusting as high as 60 mph will produce near whiteout conditions at times over higher exposed terrain.
* WHERE...In Montana, Southern Big Horn. In Wyoming, Sheridan Foothills.
* WHEN...Until noon MDT Monday.
* IMPACTS...Lower elevations, including most populated locations, will see lighter snow accumulations and minimal travel difficulties. The impactful snow accumulations will be confined to the higher hilltops, where 10 to 18 inches of heavy wet snow is expected, and locally heavier accumulations are possible. This includes Aberdeen Hill, the Wolf Mountains, and the higher terrain southeast of Sheridan.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The heavy wet snow and poor visibility will make rural travel difficult. The combination of gusty winds and wet snow may bring down tree limbs and power lines, resulting in power outages. Severe travel conditions will impact portions of I-90 over the higher terrain. An upgrade to a Winter Storm Warning is possible for these areas.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Southern Big Horn; Sheridan Foothills

cap:parameter.value: WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL NOON MDT MONDAY

This includes Lame Deer Divide and other higher terrain along US-212.

entry.title: Winter Storm Warning issued April 6 at 10:35AM MDT until April 8 at 6:00PM MDT by NWS Billings MT
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Heavy snow expected. Total snow accumulations between 1 and 3 feet. Winds gusting as high as 60 mph creating whiteout conditions at times.
* WHERE...In Montana, Pryor/Northern Bighorn Mountains. In Wyoming, Northeast Bighorn Mountains.
* WHEN...Until 6 PM MDT Monday.
* IMPACTS...Recreation in the high country will be dangerous due to very heavy snow and whiteout conditions at times. Travel on Highway 14 through Burgess Junction will likely be impossible at times. Power outages are possible due to the strong winds and wet heavy snow.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...If you plan to go to the high country this weekend be sure to let someone know your plans in case you become stranded.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Pryor/Northern Bighorn Mountains; Northeast Bighorn Mountains

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued April 7 at 2:30AM ChST until April 7 at 6:00PM ChST by NWS Tiyan GU
entry.summary:
...GUSTY WINDS AND DRY VEGETATION WILL MAINTAIN A HIGH FIRE THREAT...
* WIND...East wind 10 to 20 mph with gusts to 25 mph. Winds could be slightly higher in the higher terrain.
* HUMIDITY...50 to 60 percent, especially from late morning through sunset.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued April 6 at 10:31AM CDT by NWS Grand Forks ND
entry.summary:
Relative humidity values will drop to around 20 percent along with southeast winds gusting up to 25 mph across areas near the Lake of the Woods to Red Lakes region in northwest Minnesota. Given the dry fuels, near critical fire weather conditions are expected for the afternoon hours. Any fire that does develop has the potential to quickly spread.
For more information on burning restrictions for Minnesota, see www.dnr.state.mn.us/forestry/fire/firerating_restrictions.html

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued April 6 at 11:27AM EDT by NWS Caribou ME
entry.summary: Doppler weather radar indicates bands of heavier snow showers that will move west from New Brunswick through Eastern and Southern Aroostook County over the next several hours. These snow showers will extend into Northern Penobscot County. The snow showers may reduce visibilities to less than a one half mile at times with a quick dusting of snow. Despite temperatures above freezing the heavier snow showers will quickly cover roads and sidewalks producing slippery conditions. Use caution when driving into the afternoon by slowing down and having your headlights on. Roads that may be impacted include the US Route 1, 1A, 2 and 2A corridors along with State Route 11.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Northeast Aroostook; Northern Penobscot; Southeast Aroostook

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued April 6 at 10:26AM CDT until April 6 at 7:00PM CDT by NWS Grand Forks ND
entry.summary:
...RED FLAG WARNING FOR THE RED RIVER VALLEY AS WELL AS SOUTHEAST NORTH DAKOTA AND WEST CENTRAL MINNESOTA THIS AFTERNOON INTO THIS EVENING...
.Critical fire weather conditions are expected this afternoon and evening for the Red River Valley, southeastern North Dakota, northwest and west central Minnesota. Minimum relative humidity into the low 20s percent. Southeast winds will range from 20 to 35 mph, with gusts up to 55 mph.
The National Weather Service in Grand Forks has issued a Red Flag Warning for wind and low relative humidity, which is in effect until 7 PM CDT this evening.
* AFFECTED AREA...In Minnesota, East Marshall, Pennington, Red Lake, East Polk and Mahnomen.
* WINDS...Southeast 20 to 25 mph with gusts up to 35 mph.
* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...As low as 20 percent.
* IMPACTS...Any fires that ignite will spread rapidly and become difficult to control. Outdoor burning is not recommended.

* AFFECTED AREA...West central, southwest, and portions of south central Minnesota.
* WIND...Southeast from 25 to 30 mph, gusting 40 to 45 mph.
* HUMIDITY...20 to 30 percent.
* IMPACTS...Any fires that develop will likely spread rapidly. Outdoor burning is not recommended.

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued April 6 at 5:57AM MDT until April 6 at 8:00PM MDT by NWS El Paso Tx/Santa Teresa NM
entry.summary:
...CRITICAL FIRE WEATHER CONDITIONS WILL DEVELOP SATURDAY AFTERNOON...
.A combination of increasing west/northwest winds behind a passing cold front, low relative humidity, and continued drying of fine fuels will produce critical fire weather conditions across portions of south-central New Mexico and far west Texas on Saturday. Fuel moisture is dry enough along the desert lowlands to pose a risk of wildfire starts.
* TIMING...Noon to 8 PM Saturday.
* WINDS...West 20 to 25 mph with gusts up to 45 mph.
* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...10 to 15 percent.
* TEMPERATURES...Highs in the upper 50s to lower 60s.
* IMPACTS...Any fires that develop will likely spread rapidly. Outdoor burning is not recommended.
entry.cap:areaDesc: South Central Lowlands And Southern Rio Grande Valley; El Paso; Hudspeth

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued April 6 at 2:46AM MDT until April 6 at 8:00PM MDT by NWS Albuquerque NM
entry.summary:
...RED FLAG WARNING IN EFFECT NOON THROUGH 8 PM TODAY FOR THE MIDDLE RIO GRANDE VALLEY AND ALL OF EASTERN NEW MEXICO DUE TO STRONG WINDS AND LOW HUMIDITY...
...FIRE WEATHER WATCH IN EFFECT FROM SUNDAY MORNING THROUGH SUNDAY EVENING FOR ALL OF EASTERN NEW MEXICO DUE TO STRONG WINDS AND LOW HUMIDITY...
.Very strong westerly winds will develop by late morning behind a cold front that swept through the area this morning. Low humidity values in combination with these winds will create critical fire weather conditions for the Rio Grande Valley and all of eastern New Mexico despite well below normal temperatures. Winds will not be as strong on Sunday, but gusty westerly winds will be strong enough when combined with persistent low humidity for another round of critical fire weather conditions across eastern New Mexico.
* AREA AND TIMING...This includes the Middle Rio Grande Valley (Zone 106) this afternoon through mid evening.
* 20 FOOT WINDS... West 25 to 35 mph with gusts to 50 mph.
* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...Minimum values between 10 and 15 percent.
* IMPACTS...Any fires that develop will likely spread rapidly. Outdoor burning is not recommended.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Middle Rio Grande Valley

cap:parameter.value: RED FLAG WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM NOON TODAY TO 8 PM MDT THIS EVENING

* IMPACTS...Any fires that develop will likely spread rapidly. Outdoor burning is not recommended.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued April 6 at 3:32AM CDT by NWS Des Moines IA
entry.summary:
The combination of low relative humidity values, gusty southeasterly winds, and dry fuels will result in elevated fire weather conditions for this afternoon across much of central Iowa. Afternoon relative humidity values will fall to around 25 to 30 percent with winds of 20 to 25 mph, gusting up to 40 mph, at times.
Under these conditions, fires could start and spread easily. Please exercise caution with any activities that involve outdoor fires or create sparks, including campfires, grilling, and operating large equipment. Cigarettes should be disposed of and extinguished properly. Please heed any local burn bans.

entry.title: High Wind Warning issued April 6 at 1:26AM MDT until April 7 at 6:00PM MDT by NWS Goodland KS
entry.summary:
* WHAT...South winds at 30 to 45 mph with gusts up to 55 mph this morning, shifting to the southwest and west at 30 to 45 mph with gusts up to 65 mph this afternoon. West to northwest winds at 35 to 50 mph with gusts up to 70 mph tonight and Sunday.
* WHERE...Portions of east central and northeast Colorado, northwest and west central Kansas, and southwest Nebraska.
* WHEN...From noon MDT /1 PM CDT/ today to 6 PM MDT /7 PM CDT/ Sunday.
* IMPACTS...A prolonged period of dangerous travel and fire weather conditions. Property damage and power outages are possible in association with very strong west to northwest winds tonight and Sunday.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Strong southerly winds will rapidly shift to the southwest and west as a cold front sweeps eastward across the area late this morning and afternoon. The abrupt nature of the wind shift may catch motorists off guard. Widespread, significant reductions in visibility associated with blowing dust may accompany the frontal passage, exacerbating already difficult travel conditions. Very strong, possibly damaging, west to northwest winds are expected tonight and Sunday.

entry.title: Flood Warning issued April 5 at 9:11AM MDT by NWS Pocatello ID
entry.summary:
...The National Weather Service in Pocatello ID has issued a Flood Warning for the following rivers in Idaho...
Portneuf River at Pocatello affecting Bannock County.
For the Portneuf River...including Pocatello...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Portneuf River at Pocatello.
* WHEN...From this morning until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 8.5 feet, Sections of Sacajawea Park will be under water and the trail is usually closed at this level. Marsh Creek near Inkom may also be over its banks. At 9.2 feet, Flooding of low lying agricultural land and pasture will occur in the Inkom and Blackrock area. Lowland flooding is likely along sections of the river between Portneuf Gap and the Cheyenne Avenue Bridge in Pocatello. At 9.4 feet, Water will encroach around sitting benches near the river at the Pacific Recycling Trailhead.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 7:45 AM MDT Friday the stage was 8.7 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 7:45 AM MDT Friday was 8.7 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 9.23 feet Saturday, April 6. Additional rises are possible thereafter. - Flood stage is 8.5 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 9.4 feet on 04/26/1986. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Bannock, ID
